) Purpose: This IRM section describes the examiner’s responsibilities in devel- oping and concluding issues present in an examination. Topics addressed and include: a. Fact development. b. Rules of evidence. c. Special procedures for speciﬁc issues. d. Concluding an issue. e. Research of tax law. (

) Well-developed facts are a vital part of a quality examination. (
) You can develop the facts by:
Development and Conclusion 4.75.13

Examining the organization’s books and records. Interviewing the organization’s representatives and management. Touring the organization’s facilities. Contacting third parties to corroborate taxpayer statements and get in- formation the taxpayer fails to provide (See IRM
, Third Party Contacts).
At a minimum, to conduct a thorough examination of the books and records:

a. Determine if the books explain the organization’s activities, income, penditures, assets, and liabilities. b. Identify Large, Unusual, Questionable (LUQ) transactions. c. Reconcile amounts reported on returns to amounts totaled in the and records. d. Test the organization’s books and records for reliability. e. Evaluate how the organization is using its assets and resources. f. Identify the source and nature of the organization’s gross receipts. g. Identify the relationships of persons doing business with the exempt ganization. h. Determine whether private interests are being served at the expense the organization’s exempt purposes. i. Evaluate transactions such as purchases, sales, gifts, loans, expense imbursements, etc.
Reminder: Document all the work you perform and the conclusions you reach.

Example: You brieﬂy note each newsletter reviewed on a work paper entitled “Newsletter”. You note one article mentions an unallowable activity. You should make a copy of the article. Example: If the newsletter contains advertising you should analyze each page with ads and note your ﬁndings in the work paper. It isn’t necessary to keep a copy of the entire newsletter because you recorded the necessary details in the work papers. (

) Determining whether an item is signiﬁcant or material depends on your tion of a return as a whole and the items on the return. Consider these when determining whether an item is signiﬁcant: • Comparative size of the item - an expense item of $
would be considered large in comparison to the total expenses of $
; however, if total expenses were $
, the item would generally not be considered large. • Absolute size of the item - a $

item may be signiﬁcant even though it represents a small percentage of taxable income. • Inherent character of the item - although the amount of an item may insigniﬁcant, the nature of the item may be signiﬁcant (such as airline tickets claimed on a volunteer ﬁre department’s return). • Evidence of intent to mislead - this may include missing or incomplete schedules, mis-classiﬁed entries, or obviously incorrect items on a return. • Beneﬁcial effect of the way in which the organization reports an item - this may include expenses reported on Form
-T that aren’t directly related to the production of the organization’s UBI. • Missing items - consider items which aren’t shown on the return but would normally appear on similar taxpayers’ returns.

) A fact is something that is indisputably the case. It is a truth that can be proven. (
) Evidence, on the other hand, is a means by which the truth of an alleged is proven or refuted. It’s something that furnishes proof. (
) During an examination, you gather facts and supporting evidence to determine an organization’s status and tax liability. (

) You will base your determination on all available facts and evidence, those that support the taxpayer’s position. The following discusses the two types of evidence (oral and documentary) you’ll encounter. (
) The IRC requires all taxpayers to keep adequate records. There are to unusual circumstances, when records don’t exist. In these cases, oral testimony may be the only evidence available. (

) Follow these general guidelines when considering oral testimony: • Don’t use oral testimony in place of available documentary • Establish the credibility of the taxpayer. You can accomplish this by sidering corroborative or contradictory evidence. Example: The taxpayer was able to prove payment of the loan in question and provided a travel log and receipts for the expenses shown on the return. The taxpayer has credibility. You can, therefore, reasonably accept his/her testimony about the payment made for supplies even he/she can’t produce receipts for that expense.

The taxpayer was able to prove payment of the loan in question and provided a travel log and receipts for the travel expenses shown on the return. The taxpayer has established credibility. You can, therefore, reasonably accept his/her oral testimony about the payment made for supplies even though he/she can’t produce receipts for that expense.
Note: IRC

(d) speciﬁes record keeping rules required in certain situations. It’s permissible to allow a deduction without complete documentation if the taxpayer can show he or she has ″substantially complied″ with the adequate record keeping requirements (
CFR
)(v)). Use your skill and judgment. Treat the taxpayer fairly, but don’t allow them to proﬁt from failure to keep records.

) Send the written memorandum of interview to the taxpayer if he/she interviewee. The interviewee should conﬁrm the accuracy before you send the taxpayer. By sharing the memorandum with the taxpayer, it can be included in the administrative record. If not, the memorandum of interview likely will not be admissible evidence in court. (
) A memorandum of interview can impeach the interviewee/witness in court they deny having made the oral statement. (

) Sometimes we need a more formal written statement when documentation available and oral testimony signiﬁcantly affects the case. If you think the - may eventually be resolved through litigation, consider using an affidavit record taxpayer or third-party statements. (

) An affidavit is an attested statement and has great validity when properly prepared and voluntarily given. Affidavits may be used: a. When other documentary evidence is unavailable. b. When you want the taxpayer’s statements to become part of the ﬁle. c. To help gather complete and accurate information. d. To record the testimony of a witness. e. To prevent a taxpayer from changing testimony. (
) See IRM
) for more information on affidavits. (
) Documents are another form of evidence. (
) Send documents you obtain from a third party to the taxpayer for Evidence that they can become part of the administrative record. (

) In litigation, the court will likely admit both documentary evidence and oral testimony (in addition to the administrative record). Getting both and memoranda of interviews into the administrative record will ensure court sees the relevant evidence. (

) Fact gathering is complete after you’ve: • Interviewed taxpayers and third parties • Examined the books, records, and supporting documents • Toured facilities • Researched questionable items (

) You seldom have all of the information you’d like to resolve an issue. when you have enough to make a determination; the sooner you do, the sooner you can complete the case. This is less burdensome on you and taxpayer. (

) In arriving at a conclusion: • Make an impartial evaluation of all evidence. • Treat all taxpayers fairly and consistently. • Apply procedures and tax law fairly and consistently. • Correct mistakes made by the IRS. • Refuse to take unfair advantage of taxpayer mistakes or ignorance. (
) When you reach your conclusion for an issue, discuss it with the taxpayer representative. Provide copies of work papers, if requested. (
) Ensure your work papers document the following: • Issues considered • Evidence reviewed • Steps taken to arrive at your conclusion • Conclusion reached

) Critical to the examination process is on-going communication with the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s authorized representative. Frequently discuss the progress of the examination and proposed issues with the taxpayer. This lead to an early resolution of both the issues and the case. (
) Fully develop adjustments before presenting them to the taxpayer or tative for review. (
) Use tact when explaining proposed changes or pointing out errors in the payer’s books or records. (
) Be patient in explaining the provisions of the law, bearing in mind that what clear to you may not be clear to someone who doesn’t deal with exempt nizations in their occupation. (
) In change cases, consider providing a written summary of the issues to the taxpayer and representative. See IRM

, EO Closing Letters and Reports of Examination, for further instructions on the initial and formal procedures. a. In non-declaratory judgment cases, you can opt to prepare an initial if you reasonably expect to secure an agreement before having to a

-day letter and formal RAR. The initial RAR will contain sufficient formation to allow the taxpayer and the representative to understand issues and why you are proposing the adjustment. b. In declaratory judgment issues, prepare a formal RAR. See IRM

) Diligently secure timely responses from the taxpayer or representative. (

) An “alternative position” is a secondary position the IRS may ultimately rely if the primary position isn’t upheld. Example 2
Organization X timely ﬁled a Form 990-T, Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return, for the taxable year ended 12/31/2012 reporting $15,000 taxable income with taxes due of $2,250.

As a result of an examination of the Form 990-T for the taxable year ended 12/31/2012, you allow a NOL carryback of $4,000 from the year ended 12/31/2013. You make no other adjustments. You compute corrected taxable income as follows:
NOL carryback adjustment results in an over-assessment of
A Form 2285 is not required because the NOL carryback was from a single subsequent year and there were no current year adjustments or other carrybacks.
Form 3198-A is required. Prepare a Form 3198-A and notate in bold letters in the “Other Instructions” section “Restricted Interest IRC 6611(f). No Form 2285 is required.”
Example 3
Organization X timely ﬁled a Form 990-T, Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return, for the taxable year ended 12/31/2011 reporting $15,000 taxable income with taxes due of $2,250.

As a result of an examination of the Form 990-T for the taxable year ended 12/31/2011, you allow NOL carrybacks of $4,000 and $6,000 from the years ended 12/31/2012 and 12/31/2013, respectively. You make no other adjustments. You compute corrected taxable income as follows:
4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination
Exhibit 4.75.13-1 (Cont. 1) (04-11-2017) Restricted Interest Examples
The adjustments result in an over-assessment of $1,500 in taxes, a decrease of $600 from the NOL carryback from the year ended 12/31/2012 and a decrease of $900 from the NOL carryback from 2013.
Form 2285 is required because there are carrybacks from 2 succeeding years.
Form 3198-A is required. Prepare a Form 3198-A and notate in bold letters in the “Other section “Restricted Interest IRC 6611(f). Form 2285 is required.”
Example 4
Organization X timely ﬁled a Form 990-T, Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return, for 201212 reporting $15,000 taxable income with taxes due of $2,250.

As a result of an examination of the Form 990-T for the taxable year ended 12/31/2012, you reduce de- ductible expenses by $20,000 and allow a NOL carryback of $4,000 from the year ended 12/31/2013. You compute corrected taxable income as follows:
Income as shown on the return
The adjustments result in a deﬁciency of $2,400 in taxes, a $3,000 increase from the decrease in expenses in the examination year and a decrease of $600 from the NOL carryback from 12/31/2013.
A Form 2285 is required because there is a current year adjustment and a restricted interest from a succeeding year.

In restricted interest cases, like the one in this example, involving current year adjustments and a re- stricted interest adjustment, prepare a Form 3198-A and notate in bold letters in the “Other Instructions” section “Restricted Interest IRC 6601(d). Form 2285 is required.”
Example 5
Organization X timely ﬁled a Form 990-T, Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return, for taxable year ended 12/31/2012 reporting no taxable income.

As a result of an examination of the Form 990-T for the taxable year ended 12/31/2012, you reduce ductible expenses by $20,000 and allow a NOL carryback of $20,000 from the year ended 12/31/2013. You compute the corrected taxable income for the year ended 12/31/2012 as follows:
Income as shown on the return
Exhibit 4.75.13-1 (Cont. 2) (04-11-2017) Restricted Interest Examples

The current year adjustment, the decrease in expenses, is offset by the NOL carryback from 12/31/2013 so there is no tax as a result of the adjustments. However, the current year adjustments create a phantom tax until the NOL is available for carryback. Interest is due on this phantom tax even though there is no tax deﬁciency.
Form 3198-A is required. On the Form 3198-A notate in bold letters in the “Other Instructions” section “Assess restricted interest only - no tax deﬁciency. See Form 2285.”
